metadata.indication: BRCA-mutated ovarian, breast, and prostate cancer

evidence.snippet: A strong candidate for the breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene BRCA1 was identified; the sequence contains an open reading frame of 7,224 nt and encodes a predicted protein of 1,863 amino acids.
BRCA1 somatic mutations occur in approximately 1.3% of breast cancers, with germline BRCA1 mutations conferring a 46-87% lifetime risk of breast cancer.

Olaparib (AZD2281) induced synthetic lethality in BRCA-deficient cells at concentrations 1,000-fold lower than in BRCA-proficient cells, demonstrating selective cytotoxicity mediated by PARP inhibition.
In patients with germline BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations and advanced cancer, olaparib showed antitumor activity based on the principle of synthetic lethality.
BRCA1 and BRCA2 colocalize at discrete nuclear foci after DNA damage and interact directly with RAD51, implicating both proteins in homologous recombination-mediated DNA repair.
The BRCA1 C-terminus (BRCT) domain interacts with BRCA2 via PALB2 bridging, forming a functional complex essential for HR repair of double-strand breaks.
BRCA1 is required for homologous recombination-directed repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Cells lacking BRCA1 show a severe defect in HR and fail to form RAD51 foci after DNA damage.
BRCA1 promotes end resection of DNA double-strand breaks by facilitating CtIP phosphorylation, a critical initiating step in homologous recombination.
BRCA1 colocalizes with RAD51 in discrete nuclear foci during S phase and after DNA damage, suggesting that BRCA1 regulates RAD51-mediated strand invasion during homologous recombination.
Loss of BRCA1 leads to impaired RAD51 recruitment to sites of DNA damage, resulting in defective homologous recombination and genomic instability.
